Pros:
- Visual upgrades: Sharper textures, improved lighting, and 4K support breathe new life into the cel-shaded chaos.
- All DLCs included: Zombie Island, Mad Moxxi’s Underdome, General Knoxx, and Claptrap’s Revolution — all here.
- Mini-map and inventory tweaks: Small changes that make a big difference in usability.
- Still hilarious: The humor, characters, and loot-driven madness hold up surprisingly well.
Cons:
- Dated mission design: Lots of fetch quests and backtracking.
- AI and gunplay: Not as tight or refined as later entries.
- Co-op quirks: Occasional bugs and connection hiccups in multiplayer.

This is the definitive version of a cult classic. If you loved the original or want to see where the Borderlands mayhem began, this Enhanced edition is the way to go. Just be ready for some old-school grind and jank.

Borderlands Game of the Year Enhanced is a fantastic reminder of why this series became a cornerstone of the looter-shooter genre. While I wasn't there to play the original when it first came out, I have heard from others that the remastered visuals and improved performance of this version give it a fresh coat of paint without compromising the charm and grit that defined the original. I played from start to finish, and it’s impressive how well its core loop—shoot, loot, and repeat—still hooks you in.

What stands out most is how satisfying the gun play remains. Every weapon feels distinct, from explosive shotguns to electric sniper rifles, and the sheer variety of loot keeps experimentation fun. But my go to weapon has always been the revolver weapons. My Lv19 Masher has legit carried me the moment I got it up to Lv44. 

The RPG-style leveling and skill trees add meaningful depth to each character, encouraging different builds and playstyles. My first run was with the soldier but I ended up getting stuck on a level and made a new save with Siren and it was so much better playing as her. Maybe a bit too good. Having an on demand ability that gives you a moment of invisibility and invulnerability while also regenerating your hp? Yeah perfectly balanced. In addtion, I wasn't able to play the co-op because I prefer playing the game solo. 

That said, some aspects definitely show their age. Mission design can be repetitive, and the story, while serviceable, lacks the polish and pacing improvements found in later entries as I heard from other reviewers. But the world of Pandora still oozes personality, from its wild bandits to its grimy humor and eccentric NPCs. I am looking forward to playing the other games and learning more about the story.

In the end, Borderlands GOTY Enhanced is a great way to experience where it all began. It’s not perfect, but it’s still a blast to play—especially if you enjoy that addictive mix of action, loot, and irreverent charm. Whether you’re a returning fan or a newcomer curious about the series’ roots, this version is absolutely worth picking up.

Amazing looter shooter with a few blemishes  

There are two parts to this review, the base game and then the DLCs. First, the base game is peak, with almost perfect looter shooter mechanics, amazing drops even early on, good weapon feedback, and a pretty good art style that holds up even today. Only negatives are nitpicking, like maybe some difficulty spikes and the story/mission structure (could be more creative), but overall it's an amazing journey, but then we come to the DLCs.

DLCs are a mixed bag for me. It has good level aesthetic variation, which the base game could use, and does have some good endgame loot, but personally I feel like it comes with more issues of its own instead of fixing issues of the base game. 

Mad Moxi—Loved the 1st 5-wave mission, hate the 20-wave  

Dr. Ned/Zed - Love the aesthetics and enemies, but there is too much backtracking, and the Brainsssss mission is just mind-numbing. 

General Knoxx - Love the enemies and loot but has one of the worst bosses (Crawmerax) and more backtracking but with more distance and obstacles.

Claptrap revolution—pretty good all around. Just hated the last RNG mission but got lucky and only had to grind for 3-4 hrs. 

I would still recommend the game today, as it still holds up decently well; it's just that if you're going for 100%, it can sour the experience in the DLC section. I was going to give it "9/10," but with DLC and everything, it's "7/10." Still fun and amazing as long as you know where to look.

Borderlands 1 was an incredible game when it first came out. It offered a delightful change from the monotonous and repetitive games of its time. The addition of cartoony graphics to the realistic Mad Max-esque atmosphere created a truly captivating atmosphere. Andalso the lore details they presented throughout the game created a unique atmosphere.

With each new game, new mechanics and features were introduced to the Borderlands series. Because Borderlands 1 lacked none of these, we play it in its rawest form. If you're a new Borderlands player, you might not notice these. But when you look back at the first game after all these years, you feel like certain things were missing, leaving you feeling a sense of emptiness. For example, not being able to use a fill ammo key at vending machines or being unable to move freely for a second wind.

I think it has some positive aspects compared to later games (especially Borderlands 4). First of all, I think the game's art style is quite noticeable. I think this style has been toned down and dumbed down considerably over the years. Perhaps it's because the development team has changed a lot, breaking away from its original style, or perhaps it's because of the advancements in graphic technologies. But the most important aspect of the game style is its atmosphere. The bold lines around objects and the deep blue sky immerse you in an interesting environment.

I loved the map designs. You can almost imagine yourself traversing "living" areas. There are no civilians around, only enemies. However, these maps are included with details that reflect the possible civilians' lives and work. Garbage dumps, massive tractors, and visible factories make the game feel like you're navigating a real world.

Of course, there are some issues stemming from the inexperience of the first game. First among these are the enemy types and the unbalanced nature of the elements. When you enter an area where there seem to be no enemies at first, suddenly enemies start spawning from all sides. You're caught in the middle of a sea of enemies unprepared. You lose the opportunity to approach from afar or use tactical approaches, and you find yourself trying to escape the enemies that suddenly gather around you.

Skag, Spiderant, and Scythid all have fundamentally similar attack methods. They run at you when they see you, and they leap at you from a certain distance. This makes things even more challenging. Imagine 10 Spiderants jumping at you from different directions at once. Considering that enemies like Rakk, Psycho, Crabworm, and Guardian can also get right up to you and attack, the game becomes more of a "constantly dodging back" game than a "serious gunfight."

One reason for this may be that the game is designed for co-op with friends rather than solo play. Kiting enemies with multiple players can make the game much easier. But of course, since you can't do this solo, it makes progressing alone much more difficult. On the other hand, I think the bosses in the game die too easily. I don't even have as much trouble against the important bosses as I do with the  radom mobs I encounter. This makes me think the game's balance hasn't been adjusted properly.

The game itself was released in 2009, and the "Game of the Year Edition" in 2010. In 2019, they released a remastered version called "Borderlands Game of the Year Enhanced." They adapted Borderlands' graphics to the 4K era and introduced the minimap and character customization from Borderlands 2. However, they didn't seem to make any other improvements. You'll encounter a lot of bugs in the game, and I'd expect them to be fixed. Some are obvious, like getting stuck on the edge of objects. The mouse sensitivity settings in the game are also very poor, requiring you to modify the game files. While this would be somewhat understandable if the game were released in 2009, we're talking about a "modernized" update in 2019.

While the initial atmosphere at the start of the game is alright, a fairly desolute sci-fi wasteland, it gets pretty repetitive after a bit, especially once it all gets replaced with a trash city aesthetic for most of the last third of the game, and most content, story or side quests regardless, is both tedious and unsubstantial.

The main story missions are pretty much an excuse to just run around, shoot things, and head to the next area, with dialogue ranging from dry to unfunny, and side missions are usually laid out in the most annoying way possible, due to the single mission marker available at all times, leading to constant mindnumbing backtracking like because the third marked audio log of five of them was actually located midway between the first and second logs' position. And if it doesn't have that form of tedium, high chance you will still need to backtrack a fair distance just to hand in the quest, and that includes main story missions.

I had to resort to just resetting the game via the main menu at points due to it being sometimes minutes faster than just walking/driving to certain waypoints.

It doesn't help that there is quite a lack of polish on some basic things, main characters that have no lip sync or are generally silent during story progress, awkwardly presented cutscenes that never seem to start or end right, or just odd level design that screams rushed and unfinished. I can give it a slight pass for the time and Gearbox's team size at the time, but nowadays it just does not feel like a tight and quality-checked product overall.

I suppose the main focus then would be the gameplay, and the randomized guns, but its very unpolished and lacking, especially in comparison to the later games in the series. 

Most enemies just boil down to either some melee type thing running at you and failing to keep up as you run away, or aimbot bandits able to pinpoint hit you for quite a lot of damage across the map, making most tactics boil down to either taking cover to a jank and limited degree while you deal chip damage to them, or running up to them, one-shotting via headshots or blindly tanking the bullets, and using the 'kill or die' health state to easily get point blank headshots without much penalty. Now play like that for 30+ hours.

Guns are weirdly underdeveloped for the most part, while they feel okay-ish if the ones you are currently wielding are up-to-par with stats, it really does feel you have the bog-standard shooter loadout (pistol, shotgun, machine gun, etc.) with slight deviations in scope zoom or reloading style on the most recent guns you have looted. Even then, most of them have very unreliable accuracy until maybe late New Game Plus where you've grind the weapon specializations quite a bit, though I suppose this is to vaguely make more important class-to-weapon type specializations according to their style and skills.

After that, all the interesting weapons that try to break the mold are either quickly out-stated or extremely gimmicky, or locked off to the endgame stuff of New Game Plus where I feel most peoples excitement on the game would have burnt out unless they really want to grind them out via the limited options available at the game, and even then, there really isn't a lot to do that either hasn't been completed already, or is just aimlessly wondering the dull wastelands and trashfills shooting the same bandits you've been doing for dozens of hours. I just don't think there is remotely enough content in the game to warrant the gun randomization mechanic, much less burn hours of your life farming Borderlands 1 for more weapons that all feel the same for the most part.

I would have hoped the DLCs would spice things up a little, added quite a bit of worthy content, but beyond their theming, they really are just more Borderlands for the most part, or much worse.

The Underdome is a tedious, godawfully difficult wave-based arena that might have one of the worst forms of achievement grinds I have ever seen (complete 300 rounds I think), but even forcing myself to do the bare minimum of 75 similar playing rounds for a single skill point (and you can do that again on New Game Plus if you REALLY want to) is just egregious time wasting for no benefit.

Zombie Island DLC is a zombie-themed DLC for Borderlands.

General Knoxx DLC seems like an actual expansion more in line with normal Borderland's content, but is hampered by a lack of fast travel points and being fairly forgettable outside the limited armory you can access at the end of it, as well as some additional endgame farms to do, but I wouldn't really bother with all that, as by the time I think you would finally be doing all that, 99% of the game is probably done at that point, or so trivial at that point that grinding for 0.1% stronger guns seems incredibly pointless to me.

The Claptrap DLC idea seems fine, essentially being a last hurray of all the things you've dealt with in Borderlands + DLC with a Claptrap reskin, but its fairly short and small all things considered, but it still is more Borderlands in the truest sense, and doesn't add much to the final package of the game.

When it comes to, I feel like this is a game designed only to be enjoyed in a certain scenario in a specific timeframe in mind; Playing it with your friends in the late 2000s because Borderlands 2 or most other modern looter shooters don't exist yet, and outside of that context, its kinda boring past the early hours of playtime.

While the initial atmosphere at the start of the game is alright, a fairly desolute sci-fi wasteland, it gets pretty repetitive after a bit, especially once it all gets replaced with a trash city aesthetic for most of the last third of the game, and most content, story or side quests regardless, is both tedious and unsubstantial.

The main story missions are pretty much an excuse to just run around, shoot things, and head to the next area, with dialogue ranging from dry to unfunny, and side missions are usually laid out in the most annoying way possible, due to the single mission marker available at all times, leading to constant mindnumbing backtracking like because the third marked audio log of five of them was actually located midway between the first and second logs' position. And if it doesn't have that form of tedium, high chance you will still need to backtrack a fair distance just to hand in the quest, and that includes main story missions.

I had to resort to just resetting the game via the main menu at points due to it being sometimes minutes faster than just walking/driving to certain waypoints.

It doesn't help that there is quite a lack of polish on some basic things, main characters that have no lip sync or are generally silent during story progress, awkwardly presented cutscenes that never seem to start or end right, or just odd level design that screams rushed and unfinished. I can give it a slight pass for the time and Gearbox's team size at the time, but nowadays it just does not feel like a tight and quality-checked product overall.

I suppose the main focus then would be the gameplay, and the randomized guns, but its very unpolished and lacking, especially in comparison to the later games in the series. 

Most enemies just boil down to either some melee type thing running at you and failing to keep up as you run away, or aimbot bandits able to pinpoint hit you for quite a lot of damage across the map, making most tactics boil down to either taking cover to a jank and limited degree while you deal chip damage to them, or running up to them, one-shotting via headshots or blindly tanking the bullets, and using the 'kill or die' health state to easily get point blank headshots without much penalty. Now play like that for 30+ hours.

Guns are weirdly underdeveloped for the most part, while they feel okay-ish if the ones you are currently wielding are up-to-par with stats, it really does feel you have the bog-standard shooter loadout (pistol, shotgun, machine gun, etc.) with slight deviations in scope zoom or reloading style on the most recent guns you have looted. Even then, most of them have very unreliable accuracy until maybe late New Game Plus where you've grind the weapon specializations quite a bit, though I suppose this is to vaguely make more important class-to-weapon type specializations according to their style and skills.

After that, all the interesting weapons that try to break the mold are either quickly out-stated or extremely gimmicky, or locked off to the endgame stuff of New Game Plus where I feel most peoples excitement on the game would have burnt out unless they really want to grind them out via the limited options available at the game, and even then, there really isn't a lot to do that either hasn't been completed already, or is just aimlessly wondering the dull wastelands and trashfills shooting the same bandits you've been doing for dozens of hours. I just don't think there is remotely enough content in the game to warrant the gun randomization mechanic, much less burn hours of your life farming Borderlands 1 for more weapons that all feel the same for the most part.

I would have hoped the DLCs would spice things up a little, added quite a bit of worthy content, but beyond their theming, they really are just more Borderlands for the most part, or much worse.

The Underdome is a tedious, godawfully difficult wave-based arena that might have one of the worst forms of achievement grinds I have ever seen (complete 300 rounds I think), but even forcing myself to do the bare minimum of 75 similar playing rounds for a single skill point (and you can do that again on New Game Plus if you REALLY want to) is just egregious time wasting for no benefit.

Zombie Island DLC is a zombie-themed DLC for Borderlands.

Okay, seriously though, the Zombie DLC is near whats in the title, you get zombies. You shoot more zombies. Its got an alright campy horror vibe going on, but if you really feel like what you needed was a bunch of slow moving easily killed zombies in Borderlands to keep you going, then uh...I could recommend Left 4 Dead or something else that might keep you and your friends awake while playing.

General Knoxx DLC seems like an actual expansion more in line with normal Borderland's content, but is hampered by a lack of fast travel points and being fairly forgettable outside the limited armory you can access at the end of it, as well as some additional endgame farms to do, but I wouldn't really bother with all that, as by the time I think you would finally be doing all that, 99% of the game is probably done at that point, or so trivial at that point that grinding for 0.1% stronger guns seems incredibly pointless to me.

The Claptrap DLC idea seems fine, essentially being a last hurray of all the things you've dealt with in Borderlands + DLC with a Claptrap reskin, but its fairly short and small all things considered, but it still is more Borderlands in the truest sense, and doesn't add much to the final package of the game.

Overall, I would just say either play a later Borderlands game, or consider some other choice for multiplayer.

Also, there is a memory leak problem in this version of the game that slowly eats your frames after what I believe is enough level transitions, so I hope you enjoy constantly full restarting the game every few teleports via fast travel.
